title: Magpies ripped open ears and scratched eyes as the swooping season begins
text:
Magpie swooping season has begun across the country with reports of particularly aggressive birds ripping open ears and scratching eyes.

Jessica Wynn was out running when she was swooped multiple times with the bird's beak narrowly missing her eye.

'(The magpie) got me twice next to the eye causing two cuts that bled,' Ms Wynn posted on magpiealert.com.

Magpie swooping season has begun across the country with reports of particularly aggressive birds ripping open ears and scratching eyes

MAGPIE SAFETY Keep alert for any magpie nesting sites Birds often target individuals Wear sun glasses and a hat If a magpie swoops while you're cycling get off your bike and walk Do not provoke the magpies, they are very territorial Try making friends with the magpies by feeding them Big movements appear aggressive and provoke further attack Plan your routes to avoid magpie nesting sites Magpies have good memories and can attack the same people over subsequent seasons Source magpiealert.com

Ms Wynn is one of a number of people who have reported serious injuries in the wave of magpie swooping attacks during last few weeks.

In another incident bike rider Jordan Steele had his ear ripped open by one of the birds.

Queensland leads the country in the number of reported magpie attacks in 2019 with 1020 and 28.3 per cent of the total.

This is followed closely by Victoria at 24.6 per cent and 886 attacks.

New South Wales has had the third largest share of the feathered dive-bombers at 20.8 per cent and 750 attacks.

The Australian Capital Territory has 16.7 per cent with about 600 attacks.

While Western Australia and South Australia have about 5 per cent each with about 120 reported incidents.

The number of magpie attacks across Australia has jumped from just a handful reported in July to about 600 in September.

The activity that attracts the most attacks from the territorial animals is cycling at 69 per cent.

This is followed by walking at 22.8 per cent.

There is then a huge gap with running third at just 3.2 per cent.

Some safety tips to avoid magpie attacks include planning your route to avoid nesting sites, getting off your bike near nesting sites, and wearing a hat and sunglasses.
